oai_dc:dc.dc:title: SEA-AIR INTERACTIONS IN THE COSTAL CIRCULATION AROUND GRAN CANARIA ISLAND (SPAIN)
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tejedor, Begona
Alejo, Miguel
Tejedor, Luis
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Gran Canaria Island
sea-air interaction
circulation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This paper presents the results of analyzing six months of simultaneous records of water levels, currents, wind and atmospheric pressure that have been collected outside the surf zone at three locations in the eastern coast of Gran Canaria (Canary Islands, Spain) . The results shown in this paper concern mainly one of the coastal stations, placed at the port of Las Palmas city. Although tides and currents use to be astronomically dominated, a non-permanent term appears in certain time intervals, identified as a long wave -rotary type- with a frequency very close to the inertial one. Another interesting result is the appearance of harmonic tidal periodicites in the atmospheric variables, which suggest a higher importance of the meteorological tides or/and a strong interaction sea-air.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 22 (1990): Proceedings of 22nd Conference on Coastal Engineering, Delft, The Netherlands, 1990.
